summary: This document is an email chain from December 2007 discussing the selection of a special master in the Epstein case, confusion over who concurred with the selection of Mr. Ocariz, and a request for a de novo review of evidence underlying a proposed indictment. It reveals internal DOJ communications and procedural steps.

persons.name: Bert
persons.context: Originally nominated to be the special master in the Epstein case, but his nomination led to complications when he sent a list of questions.

persons.name: Jay
persons.role: DOJ official involved in special master selection
persons.context: Requested a list of acceptable people for special master, including candidates from Podhurst, and there is confusion over whether he originally concurred with the selection of Mr. Ocariz.

persons.name: Ocariz
persons.context: Had been told that Jay concurred in his selection, but then was informed of the office's decision to use a special master, causing confusion.

connections.description: Jay requested a list of acceptable people for special master after Bert was originally nominated.
There is confusion over whether Jay originally concurred with the selection of Ocariz as special master.

events.title: Special Master Selection Discussions
events.description: Internal DOJ email chain discussing the nomination and selection process for a special master in the Epstein case, involving Bert, Jay, and Ocariz.

events.title: Request to Pull Evidence Together
events.description: An email indicates intent to start pulling everything together, including state interview audio/videotapes, and a drafted letter to Jay.

events.title: De Novo Review Requested
events.description: In light of recent Kirkland & Ellis correspondence, a de novo review of the evidence underlying the proposed Epstein indictment is requested.

keyFacts: There was internal confusion at the DOJ over whether official 'Jay' originally concurred with the selection of 'Mr. Ocariz' as special master.
A de novo review of the evidence underlying the proposed Epstein indictment was requested in December 2007, prompted by recent correspondence from the law firm Kirkland & Ellis.
The email chain reveals procedural delays and communication issues, including 'radio silence' after the special master issue was raised.
